text: the worst possible time to determine when you should roll an option is when the trade is on what that means is we should think about it ahead of time so the goal of this video is to walk you through a formula on how you can think about rolling options what the best time to roll an option is but then most importantly the different considerations you should think about as you're going through the process of rolling an option let's get right in so very first thing is a market disposition this is the same thing you'll see most of my content and it's because overviewing the market in your portfolio upfront is probably one of the most important steps you can take as a Trader it informs everything else that we're doing so if I'm looking at any position and I'm thinking if I want to roll it a big part of that is what do I think about the market what do I think about the portfolio and how this position fits into the portfolio all of that informs the way I think about rolling now a couple other general concepts says it pertains to Rolling first off when we're referring to Rolling most often we're referring to a short option that is fallen in the money meaning we would be closing it for a loss and opening a new trade but that's just kind of colloquially speaking rolling can occur at any point in time

text: first off when we're referring to Rolling most often we're referring to a short option that is fallen in the money meaning we would be closing it for a loss and opening a new trade but that's just kind of colloquially speaking rolling can occur at any point in time rolling an option is simply when we close one open another and we're tying the accounting to one another it's nothing more than that so you can roll winning positions you can roll out of the money positions you can roll bought or sold positions it's just two transactions now for General context here and most often you're going to hear to people rolling positions that they're defending something that's going against them so that part aside we have kind of our first step out of the way what's the next step well this is one that most people Overlook and it's probably one of the most important things they need to ask themselves should you be in this Trade A lot of people have a position that they put on it starts to go against them and then they're like ah I got to defend this but maybe we're just wrong maybe the best move is actually to get out of the trade not tie up Capital into something that's not working and then to deploy our Capital somewhere more logical so the way to think about this is first I don't like the question of what I put

text: just wrong maybe the best move is actually to get out of the trade not tie up Capital into something that's not working and then to deploy our Capital somewhere more logical so the way to think about this is first I don't like the question of what I put the position on now because that assumes that over the entire life cycle of a trade that you would have optimal entry points and that's just not real that's not how trading works even trades that are working there's very commonly instances where I wouldn't put that trade on right now so I actually don't like that I get the idea and it's designed to get you to do this but as usual I prefer to get a little more specific so the real question I have is am I defending a loser just because of my ego and because I don't want to have a losing trade or is there a logical reason behind it that is the question to ask here and we'll get into an example in just a couple minutes the next piece we have is this which is what is the optimal time to roll well in an Ideal World your optimal time to roll would be when the stock price is the same as your strike price and there's no extrinsic value remaining this is a goldilock scenario you're essentially never going to see this it could happen but it's insanely infrequent most often

text: even with weeklys will have more expirations the closer into time you get typically within 60 days but once you get outside 60 days then the date Windows start to jump massively in this case you have 49 days until you get to the next cycle and this can be even worse if you're trading something that's less liquid so if you're trading something like qld notice you don't have that many choices you go from 3 to 38 to 129 so expiration liquidity is actually really important part of this puzzle because my general disposition is to go as little far out in time as I can here's why if I'm in the position of Defending something that's not going in my favor so if we Zoom this out more and I'm going and I'm trying to fight this thing that's going in the wrong way you have a couple choices you could go really far out in time get a bigger basis adjustment but then if it keeps going down what's happening in that scenario is let's say you rolled it from this 10 to the 45 you get a really nice basis adjustment but let's say it keeps plummeting well now you can't really adjust your basis as much much because now instead of just being able to jump 30 days you're going to have to jump increasing periods of time that kind of lock you into holding the position even though something could be nose diving

text: keeps plummeting well now you can't really adjust your basis as much much because now instead of just being able to jump 30 days you're going to have to jump increasing periods of time that kind of lock you into holding the position even though something could be nose diving so it's very Market dependent but it's something to think about my typical disposition is if I'm defending a trade I want to go as little out in time so I can maintain spot price sensitivity so the last thing here is profit potential now if I have no inventory preference and expiration liquidity looks good meaning I have tons of choices then I'm going to look at which one gives me the most ways to make money and what that means is let's take a look at this example again if I go in this trade and again let's say that we have these 204s let's say that you choose to roll out to this 16 DTE so this 204 you would make more money if you kept it right here at the 204 because you would collect more extrinsic value however your basis would be the same so if you wanted to roll out and then down to get away from being at the money and this is the same for the call side then all of a sudden you're collecting less Theta so your trade makes less money so this also becomes a pretty big calculus specifically

text: if you wanted to roll out and then down to get away from being at the money and this is the same for the call side then all of a sudden you're collecting less Theta so your trade makes less money so this also becomes a pretty big calculus specifically for covered calls because if you have long shares and if you're able to roll up for your long shares that means that you're able to sell them instead of 203 at 204 so you might sacrifice some of the time value of your options because you'll make more money on the long stock you have to look at that pretty carefully so this is really the series we're looking at though how do I feel about inventory what am I trying to do with my basis if I'm trying to more aggressively adjust my basis that tells me I'm going to sacrifice how much money I potentially am going to make in extrinsic value because I'm trying to get a bigger change in my basis the time value left in the options is always a tricky Prospect I prefer to let as much time value run away as I can however again if you do that and something Falls too far in the money that's when you get stuck and you can't adjust your strike or your bases anymore so again if you don't care about adjusting your bases then that probably doesn't matter so much you wait until
